reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 26, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Davenport and Flowers Together Again
reviews.reviewText: First, some background. Many years ago, John Sandford began the “Prey” series. These novels all feature protagonist Lucas Davenport. We meet Davenport as a Minneapolis Police Detective Lieutenant. After an extremely eventful career, during the course of which he becomes very wealthy developing on line games and marries an extraordinarily skilled plastic surgeon, he moves to the Minnesota Bureau of Criminal Apprehension, a state level mini FBI. His adventures continue. He retires and is appointed a Deputy U.S. Marshal at the behest of some very influential federal level politicians whom he rescued from the clutches of desperate criminals. Davenport isn’t a regular Deputy. He has sort of a roving commission, dictated by his very influential sponsors. He unofficially joins a variety of federal investigations.Sandford, some time after beginning the “Prey” series, began a second series featuring BCA Agent Virgil Flowers. Flowers is assigned to a satellite office and assists other police agencies. He is an outdoorsman. Sort of a “flower child” cop. As a sideline, he writes articles for wildlife magazines. While encountering and dealing with a variety of sociopaths. And is about to publish his first novel while working on the second.Several books ago, Sandford decided to partner Davenport and Flowers. This is, I believe, the third joint adventure.Any of the books in either series can be read as a standalone. I’ve been with both since the beginning and heartily recommend both series and the partnership adventures. But, caution, reading all of them is easily a forty book commitment.Now, to the quibble. I’m a retired prosecutor. I look for authenticity in this genre. The books were very authentic…until Davenport became a free lance Deputy Marshal. Now, the premise isn’t implausible. It’s impossible. But, setting this aside, the books, including this one are exceptionally well written. The police seem real. The criminals, especially the sociopaths, are chilling. Sandford’s dialogue is absolutely superb. Especially, the “filler” conversations. They are,in my opinion, unmatched.This book opens with Lucas and Virgil recuperating from serious gunshot wounds sustained in the last book. Note…in Sandford’s books, the good guys frequently are injured, shot, and occasionally are killed. That gives each book an added edge.A Federal District Court Judge and his two sons are cold bloodedly murdered in a home invasion. The Judge’s wife, an actress and university lecturer is fortunately away from home. The killer spares their infant daughter. This is a joint local, state, federal investigation. Davenport is requested to “drop in” to the investigation because of the victim’s prominence. Flowers is assigned by the BCA to join Davenport. They shadow the investigation which leads to an unrelated white collar scam involving a charitable umbrella association. Davenport and Flowers slowly unravel the cases. Unbeknownst to them (for a while) they are being shadowed by the Judge’s widow, intent on revenge. There are very suspenseful chase/stalking situations, a couple more murders, and a very meticulous, if somewhat confrontational investigation by our heroes. All of which lead to a satisfactory resolution. The characters are anything but one dimensional. The widow’s thirst for revenge is very interesting. And, there are some surprise reveals. All in all, this is a superb, character driven procedural that I highly recommend.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 18, 2023
reviews.reviewText: as usual. While I laughed at some Virgil-Lucas word play, I didn’t have the lol moments I’m used to with the Prey series. Except a few insignificant references to their young kids, it’s like they weren’t parents at all.SPOILERS: Not having a clear reason for the Sand murders and why Hess felt it was so necessary to kill Maggie has left a big hole; yes, it’s fiction but good fiction & unlike Sandford to leave gaping holes. The insinuation that Hess “may” have hit on one of the boys is not enough, especially, when pushed, Maggie immediately hit on Hess - why? And no one talking or pushing Maggie to seek mental health is a big loss. (Although, if anyone had harmed a hair on my kids head, I would have gone crazy; not sure I would have been up to meticulous planning & I would probably have been caught & gone to jail.)

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Never ever a disappointing moment
reviews.reviewText: Davenport and Flowers always end up in the soup up to their earlobes. Sandford spins a tale like no one else can. I pick up so much of my retired police officer brother in how he presents his characters that I often think he too spent time in a patrol car. A really great story, as usual. These are the makings of screenplays for a great TV series. When will the producers pick up on such a golden opportunity?

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 29, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars I love the “Prey” Series!
reviews.reviewText: John Sandford has given the reader such well-developed characters that it feels as if I really know them. There were two plots - maybe three - if you consider the mental journey of one of the main characters. Lucas and Virgil know each other so well. I hope Sandford continues writing about them. On a side note, there was quite a bit of humor sprinkled in. Maybe Sandford can get a gig in stand-up comedy.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Davenport and Flowers
reviews.reviewText: It's hard to write 33 books using the same characters, but Sandford keeps doing it well. The plot is solid, and the players play their parts very well. Their are enough twists and turns to keep the reader interested. My misgivings are that there is nothing new. All the characters seem formularized, and although new, the plot seems to be a retread of old plots jumbled all together. There is also only occasional comedic side chatter. I miss other characters that supply that chatter, such as the 2 large detectives seen in prior novels. Overall, though, it is a very readable novel, by a master author.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 20, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars A quick read
reviews.reviewText: Despite Sandford's ridiculous political notions that seem to seep into his stories continually, this was a good read. Sandford does believable dialog that keeps the ot moving.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2024
reviews.reviewText: I am a big fan of John Sanford books. This one did not disappoint. I enjoyed both Lucas and Virgil investigating together. The story was not what I expected and had a few twists.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Typical John Sanford.
reviews.reviewText: The man just never disappoints! This is one of the best ones for he and Virgil. A blast from start to finish.

reviews.reviewerName: josé Guadalupe de la Luz Gómez Villarreal
reviews.reviewTitle: buen plot, quizá los diálogos entre davenport y flowers ocupan más paginas que lo podría ser sensato
reviews.reviewText: bien en general, las novelas de sanford siempre son buena y ágil lectura
Like every other book in the Prey series, this one is fast-paced, and exciting. One star is lost for me due to the weak ending.

Another good Prey series read. Lucas is older and recovering from a shooting and as happens to all of us he feels the pains of being older creeping up on him, but he still wants to catch the bad guys. Flowers has never been my favourite, but they worked well together as a team and their banter was pretty good. It must be difficult for Mr Sandford must be struggling to bring new and exciting stories to this series, but he succeeded once again. Hope he can keep going there was a hint of a character for his next book. Hopefully he won’t be like Mr Child and give his character to someone else as that has not worked for Reacher. I actually wish they had killed him off in a last good story that keep going with poor writing.
Lucas and Virgil back at it in another adventure to catch a criminal. Always a very satisfying read from John Sandford.
